div.head: Report:
div.p: The central aspect of this proposal was to combine small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) with radiography during a laser-driven shocks that are frequently employed to produce high pressures. The conditions achieved in these experiments can vary from those achieved in static compression using diamond-anvil cells, due to the dynamic nature of the shock generation and of the temporal response of the material. This is particularly true at high strain rates. The central aspect of this proposal was to combine small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) with radiography exploiting the coherence properties of the X-ray beam. The X-rays were generated by the means of two undulators. XPCI was per-formed 145 m from the source to achieve enhanced partial spatial coherence of the X-ray beam. Shock wave compression in the sample was generated using a 6J or ~1J, ~10 ns pulsed laser. The laser pulse and the image acquisition were synchronized with the X-ray pulses using the RF of storage ring as the master clock. XPCI images were recorded by a high-spatial resolution, ultra-highspeed indirect X-ray detector [1].
